title: makesure v0.9.21 â€“ whatâ€™s new?
kiteticker-async: Async client for the Kite Connect WebSocket API
description:
My first Rust crate. Kite is a popular trading platform in India that also exposes APIs for algo trading in the form of Kite Connect APIs (https://kite.trade/docs/connect/v3/). However, their official SDK for Rust is unmaintained, and the ticker APIs, i.e., WebSockets streaming implementations, had many design issues. As a result, I wrote spaghetti code while developing an algo-trading client app using Tauri.

I decided to write my own WebSockets streaming implementation following Kiteâ€™s protocol documentation (https://kite.trade/docs/connect/v3/websocket/#binary-market-data) rather than using the Ticker APIs of kiteconnect-rs (the official SDK). And this crate is just the open-source version of that attempt.
description_plain:
My first Rust crate. Kite is a popular trading platform in India that also exposes APIs for algo trading in the form of Kite Connect APIs (https://kite.trade/docs/connect/v3/). However, their official SDK for Rust is unmaintained, and the ticker APIs, i.e., WebSockets streaming implementations, had many design issues. As a result, I wrote spaghetti code while developing an algo-trading client app using Tauri. 

I decided to write my own WebSockets streaming implementation following Kite's protocol documentation (https://kite.trade/docs/connect/v3/websocket/#binary-market-data) rather than using the Ticker APIs of kiteconnect-rs (the official SDK). And this crate is just the open-source version of that attempt.

title: CHERIoT: Complete Memory Safety for Embedded Devices

submitter_user.about:
I am a former Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research Cambridge and a Visiting Researcher at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory, working on hardware/software co-design for cloud security.  We recently released a [high-performance memory allocator](https://github.com/Microsoft/snmalloc), which was designed to be used with the [Verona language](https://github.com/Microsoft/Verona).  I remain actively involved in the [CHERI](https://chericpu.org) project, where I led the early language / compiler strand of the research.  

I was on the FreeBSD Core Team for two terms, have been an LLVM developer since 2008, am the author of the GNUstep Objective-C runtime (libobjc2 and associated clang support), and am responsible for libcxxrt and the BSD-licensed device tree compiler.
